headline.main: Massachusetts Man's Goal Is to Rid Town of Tobacco

docs.abstract: Ralph Sirianni, retired state lawmaker in Massachusetts, has turned town of Winthrop, Mass, into new front in tobacco wars with proposal that town ban sale of all tobacco products there; American Cancer Society and Tobacco Institute say such a proposal has never been made before; anti-smoking groups are delighted, but many townspeople are less than thrilled; one local merchant calls idea unconstitutional; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: From this well-worn seaside town beneath the planes roaring into the nearby Boston airport, 74-year-old Ralph Sirianni watched the unveiling of the tobacco industry settlement this summer with mounting discontent. He also watched teen-agers continue to light up their illicit afternoon smokes not 20 feet from school.

headline.main: CIGARETTE MAKERS REACH SETTLEMENT IN NONSMOKER SUIT

docs.abstract: Major tobacco companies settle with estimated 60,000 former and current flight attendants and their survivors first class-action suit over effects of smoking on nonsmokers, agreeing to spend $300 million for study of tobacco-related diseases; does not acknowledge that second-hand smoke is harmful and will pay plaintiffs themselves nothing, even though plaintiffs' lawyers will receive $49 million in fees and costs; terms of settlement discussed; lead plaintiff, Norma Broin, comments; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The major tobacco companies today settled the first class-action lawsuit over the effects of smoking on nonsmokers by agreeing to spend $300 million for the study of tobacco-related diseases. In settling with an estimated 60,000 former and current flight attendants and their survivors, the industry did not acknowledge that secondhand smoke was harmful and will pay the plaintiffs themselves nothing. But the plaintiffs' lawyers will receive $49 million in legal fees and costs.
